Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research/RUI: Factors that Affect the Likelihood of Prejudice Confrontation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will advance understanding in the area of prejudice and stigma reduction by contributing to understanding the obstacles people face in prejudice confrontation. Prejudice remains a significant and frequent experience for members of stigmatized groups; one with important consequences for physical and psychological well-being. Previous research on prejudice reduction demonstrates that one effective way to decrease prejudice is to confront it when it occurs. Not only does prejudice confrontation reduce subsequent expressions of prejudice, but it also empowers victims of prejudice. Despite these positive consequences of prejudice confrontation, people often refrain from confronting the prejudice they witness. Understanding the factors that predict whether people will confront prejudice would benefit our understanding of an important social psychological phenomenon. The project also includes development of a training program to teach people how to overcome the obstacles to confrontation.

This research builds on previous knowledge about prejudice confrontation. The first set of studies investigates participants' judgments about the urgency of taking action against prejudice by measuring perceptions of harm and injustice as a function of the type of prejudice, target presence, and witness reactions. The second set of studies measures participants' perceptions of responsibility for confronting prejudice as a function of the number of witnesses, target presence, and role accountability. The third and final set of studies examines whether participants confront prejudice as a function of perceptions of confrontation self-efficacy and outcome expectancies. Importantly, this research can provide a base from which to build training programs to empower those who witness prejudice to voice their disapproval, and ultimately these findings may generalize and be useful in attenuating the occurrence of other incivilities (e.g., bullying, teasing).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous research points to the ongoing challenge of social biases (stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination) in contemporary society; women and members of traditionally stigmatized groups continue to report experiencing biases that are both subtle and overt in their daily lives. Reducing intergroup biases is complex, but research points to the value of speaking up – i.e., confronting prejudice—as a viable strategy for promoting equitable social norms and reducing individual level expression and support for social biases. People often want to speak up and when they do, they report great psychological benefit in addition to the benefits of prejudice reduction. But speaking up can also be difficult to do; both lab research and survey studies suggest that people want to speak up more often that they actually want to do so.

Bystander intervention theory and research, first proposed to understand reactions to physical emergencies, offers a framework for understanding  barriers to speaking up when prejudice occurs. In particular, bystander intervention research points to the importance of disambiguating harmful situations and recognizing the need for a response in predicting whether bystanders respond in physical emergencies. When people fail to see that another person needs help –because the person seems unharmed or the person responds as though the injury is small—people are less likely to help. A parallel analogy can be drawn to confronting social biases: people may fail to recognize the urgency or harm that targets can experience when bias occurs, leading them to be less likely to speak up when prejudice occurs. Given much contemporary bias is subtle and implicit and the reality that targets are often reticent react for fear of backlash, non-target bystanders to
bias may not respond to biases simply because they do not recognize a response may be warranted or helpful.

The goal of the current research was to understand whether perceptions that social biases are less harmful, intentional, and urgent diminishes the ikelihood that bystanders will speak up when they witness everyday incidents of prejudice. We conducted two studies to determine whether we could assess perceptions of the harm, intent, and urgency of bias. In addition, we considered whether targets’ presence or their reactions to bias might disambiguate the potential harm of biases with implications for prejudice confrontation. In both studies, participants witnessed a racist remark in what they believed was a real-time online chat via the internet. Across both studies, we manipulated whether the remark was overtly hostile or more subtle and whether a target of the bias was present or absent (in the chat room, Study 1; in the research setting, Study 2) when the remark occurred. In Study 2, we also manipulated how the other person in the room responded (neutrally or with negative surprise). We gave participants in both studies a chance to respond to the chat participants and coded their responses for evidence of confrontation. We also asked participants to tell us what they thought about the comments and the people purported to have been in the chatroom. Preliminary results suggest some support for our hypotheses; people were more likely to confront the biases when the comments were overtly hostile and they viewed these comments as more harmful. But other participant data point to caution in interpreting these data; when asked about the purpose of our study, most participants mentioned something directly relevant to our hypotheses, suggesting their reactions may have been vulnerable to demand characteristics. Conducting research on racial attitudes and responses to bias may be more difficult to do in times when the society is addressing these issues more openly, as we see in our current social context in the US.

This research advances our understanding of factors that may facilitate or inhibit confrontation of everyday incidents of bias. Although the preliminary data from these studies suggests some challenges to studying these issues given discussions about race and bias in our society, they suggest future
avenues for studying reactions to prejudice beyond targets’ reactions. Broader impacts from this research include training for 31 undergraduate research assistants who gained research experience in social science and support for career development/evaluating possible graduate training in social sciences.
